did.head: Collection Summary

repository.corpname: Woodson Research Center, Rice University, Houston, Texas

did.unittitle: Peter Gardner collection
did.abstract: This collection consists of digitized wav and mp3 files, along with jpeg images of the original 2-track audio reels created by Peter Gardner.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Born in 1933, Peter Gardner grew up in Cleveland. He attended Haverford College in Pennsyylvania receiving a Bachelor's degree in Psychology and a Master's degree in Music.

From the late 1950s to the early 1960s, he toured the United States and Europe with his then wife, Isabelle Ganz, under the stage name The Gardners. They recorded two albums, entitled "Peter and Isabel; The Gardners" (1962) and "Folksongs Far and Near" (1963).

The couple eventually settled in Houston in 1962, when Peter Gardner became the Director of Adult Activities at the Jewish Community Center. In this role, he organized a seasonal folk music series. Starting in 1965 and ending in 1966, he hosted the KRBE show "The Sampler" from his home at 716 W. Alabama in Houston.

During this time period, he opened up his home to pickin' parties where folk singers Guy Clark and Townes Van Zandt met. The Jewish Community Center folk series influenced a generation of Houston folk musicians with performances by John A. Lomax, Jr., Lightnin' Hopkins, and Mance Lipscomb.
In 1969, Peter Gardner moved to the Boston area. He became a practicing psychotherapist, as well as a consultant. He lived in the area until he passed in 1993.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This collection consists of digitized wav and mp3 files, along with jpeg images of the original 2-track audio reels created by Peter Gardner. This audio mainly covers live recordings at the Jewish Community Center and live tapings of the radio show "The Sampler."

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Request access to this digital material (stored on Fondren Library's nearline / non-public server) by contacting Woodson Research Center staff at woodson@rice.edu. Please use the Identifier number in your request. This material is open for research.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Donated by Matthew Gardner in September 2018.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Peter Gardner collection, 1959-1966, MS 779, Woodson Research Center, Fondren Library, Rice University

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Permission to publish from this material must be obtained from the Peter Gardner family, as well as any content copyright holders.

did.unittitle: Jewish Community Center Concert - Music for Strings

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: These digitized audio files consist of one master copy wav, one access copy mp3, and jpg images of the reel, box, and any ephemera.

Contents include: Handel - Overture to "Theodora" for Strings and Klavier; Mozart - Concerto #3 for Cembalo in E Flat Major K. 107 from a Clavier Sonata by Johann Christian Bach; Geminaiani - Concerto Grosso in B Flat Major, Op. 3, No. 5 for Strings and Klavier; Telemann - Concerto for Violin and Violincello in E Major; Locatelli - Concerto Grosso for String Orchestra and Klavier in E. Major, Op. 1, no. 6. Musicians include: Violins: Fredell Lack Eichhorn, Juri Jelagin, Richard Collins, Doris Musgrave; Violas: Wayne Crouse, Violetta Moncada; Violincello: Shirley Trepel; Contrabass: Philip Edley; Cembalo and Musical Director: Albert Hirsh

did.unittitle: Jewish Community Center Concert - Houston Folklore Society, reel 1 and 2

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: These digitized audio files consist of one master copy wav, one access copy mp3, and jpg images of the reel, box, and any ephemera.

Contents include: Reel 1: John A. Lomax, Jr. describes the society, its history, and is the master of ceremonies. Davy Jones - "East Virginia," "Bobby Campbell"; Rick Kelly and Bob Stetson - "The Road to Freedom," "I'm Going Home"; Mrs. Joe Liday [?] - "Battle of New Orleans," "Lass from the Low Country"; Mike Rickard [?] and George Lyons [?] - "Mr. Tambourine Man," "Call Me Lonesome"; Carolyn Terry - "Shake Sugaree," "The Demon Lover"; Tom Reeve [?] - "Freight Train," "900 Miles"; Brian Evans and Dave Singleton - "River Is Wide," Peter, Paul and Mary instrumental; John Rogers - "Come My Son". Reel 2: Contents include: John A. Lomax, Jr. is the master of ceremonies. Hank Slaughter - "Tell Old Bill," "Goodbye Rosalita"; Ken Boggs - Instrumental, "Empty Pocket Blues"; Linda Miller - "Donna Donna," "Five Hundred Miles," "Two Brothers"; Joe Johnson, Bill Taylor, and Michael White - "Steel Guitar Rag," "Beaumont Rag," Instrumental; Sharon Steenberg - "Bittersweet," "Remember the Alamo"; Pete Wheeler - "Poor Little Turtledove," "Little Margaret"; George Lyons [?] - "All I Really Want to Do," "She Loves You," "Blues in My Bottle," "Motorcycle Song"; Recording abruptly ends.
